polished_script:
HOOK: The $50 million agents never complain about difficult clients. [ON-SCREEN: $50M agents have no "difficult" clients]

BRAND INTRO: "This is D.J. Paris with Keeping It Real Podcast, and this is your agent tip of the day."

SETUP: You know that feeling when a client texts you at 9 PM, or wants to see the same house three times, and you're internally rolling your eyes thinking "here we go again"? Most agents see client demands as interruptions to their day. [ON-SCREEN: Client texts at 9 PM = interruption?]

[15-SEC RE-HOOK]: But Kristee Leonard, who moves over $50 million in Austin luxury real estate annually, sees it completely differently.

INSIGHT: When I asked Kristee about client management, she said something that stopped me cold: "It's an honor to be chosen by clients, and I treat them like they're an honor." [ON-SCREEN: "I treat them like they're an honor"] Not tolerate. Not manage. Honor. That 9 PM text? That's someone who trusted her with their biggest financial decision. Three showings? That's someone making sure they get it right. [ON-SCREEN: Reframe = everything changes]

REFRAME: Here's what happens when you make this shift: You stop resenting the work, you stop complaining about clients, and they absolutely feel that energy. That energy difference is what separates a one-time transaction from a referral machine that builds a $50 million business.

CTA: "So be honest ‚Äî do your clients feel honored to work with you, or do they feel like they're bothering you?"

CLOSE: "See you next time."

---

CAPTION: The mindset shift that separates $50M agents from everyone else üè†‚ú® #RealEstate #ClientService

HASHTAGS: #RealEstate #RealtorTips #ClientService #LuxuryRealEstate #RealtorMindset

SHAREABLE_MOMENT: "It's an honor to be chosen by clients, and I treat them like they're an honor."

PERFORMANCE_NOTES: 
1. Deliver the hook with conviction ‚Äî pause after "never complain" for emphasis
2. Slow down and soften tone when delivering Kristee's actual quote ‚Äî let it land
3. Lean forward slightly during the reframe section to create intimacy and urgency
